table-wrap.anchoringText: At intermediate levels, criteria and sub-criteria are compared pairwise to generate fuzzy judgment matrices. The fuzzified scale of 1-9 (Table 1), which is capable of capturing vagueness in perception, is used to assign relative importance to the pairwise comparison (Hamidi et al., 2008).
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Fuzzy numbers used for making pairwise comparisons

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fuzzy numbers used for making pairwise comparisons

tr.td:
a Δ is a fuzzification factor and assumed to be 1 in this study
In (a, b, c), a, b and c are the minimum, most likely and maximum values, respectively.
Intermediate values between two adjacent judgments

table-wrap.anchoringText: where RI is the random index, whose values are tabulated in Table 2. To ensure consistency, CR is not supposed to exceed the threshold value of 0.1.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Random index used to compute consistency ratio (CR)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Random index used to compute consistency ratio (CR)

table-wrap.anchoringText: In this step, fuzzy weights are calculated for each criterion. This can be realized by various methods including eigenvectors, arithmetic means and geometric means, which provide insignificant differences (Hamidi et al., 2008). In this study, the geometric mean method is adopted. To apply this method, one needs to manipulate fuzzy arithmetic operations over fuzzy pairwise comparison matrices. The details of fuzzy arithmetic operations are described in Table 3.
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Common fuzzy arithmetical operations using two TFNs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Common fuzzy arithmetical operations using two TFNs

table-wrap.anchoringText: Good match was obtained between the experimental and simulated PVT behavior in terms of GOR, the formation volume factor and viscosities, as illustrated in Figure 5. Compositions of the three fluids are compared in Figure 6 and values of fluid properties are tabulated in Table 4. It is worth mentioning that the effect of temperature was not considered in this study and relevant properties were calculated at a fixed reservoir temperature of 150 °F.
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: Summary of fluid properties

tr.td: Formation volume factor, rvb/stb @ saturation pressure

table-wrap.anchoringText: The base case model established in this study was one section (640 acres) of the Pembina Cardium field with a uniform reservoir thickness of 30 ft. The input parameters for the reservoir model are tabulated in Table 5. It is assumed that the whole field is well maintained with good pressure support. Therefore, initial reservoir pressure is a function of depth and is calculated as the product of the reservoir depth and a pressure gradient of the Pembina Cardium field (0.58 psi/ft) (IHS, 2016).
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: Reservoir input for the base case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir input for the base case

tr.td:
aParameters may be varied for sensitivity analysis
bThis parameter is a function of formation depth
Depth at the top of formation, ft

table-wrap.anchoringText: Typically, a stimulated reservoir volume (SRV) is estimated from microseismic event cloud mapping. For simplicity, SRV in this model is represented by a permeability enhanced area around wellbore, as illustrated in Figure 7, and defined as the product of fracture length, well lateral length and formation thickness. Other than permeability, properties within and outside of SRV are assumed to be the same. Table 6 summarizes the properties of the wells and hydraulic fractures, along with operation conditions for the base case. A close view of LGR applied to one of the fractures and the 3D base case model are depicted in Figure 8.
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Properties of wells, fractures and operating conditions for the base case

formatted-caption.caption-text: Properties of wells, fractures and operating conditions for the base case

tr.td:
aParameters may be varied for sensitivity analysis
bS.P. is abbreviated form of saturation pressure
cThis parameter is a function of formation depth
Maximum oil production rate per well, stb/d

table-wrap.anchoringText: Table 7 and 8 provide a summary of all criteria considered and the levels associated with each. The D-optimal design was applied to generate simulation runs. A total of 20 runs and 16 runs were required for the reservoir quality group and the well completion quality group, respectively. By using the aforementioned reservoir model, recovery factors were obtained through compositional simulations of a 10-year CO2 injection. The generated simulation runs and the corresponding recovery factor for each run are tabulated in Table 9 and Table 10.
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Reservoir quality criteria and the associated levels for sensitivity runs

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reservoir quality criteria and the associated levels for sensitivity runs

The generated simulation runs and the corresponding recovery factor for each run are tabulated in Table 9 and Table 10.

table-wrap.anchoringText: For the purpose of grading and ranking candidate well pads, an optimal set of reservoir and well completion parameters that provides for the best CO2-EOR performance was searched by applying numerical simulations on the base case. Nearly a hundred simulation runs were carried out, with the results demonstrated in Figures 11 and 12. The values of parameters that optimize process performance, as given by the simulation runs, are listed in Table 13.
table-wrap.label: Table 13
table-wrap.caption: Fuzzy weights, global weights and optimum value of each criterion

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fuzzy weights, global weights and optimum value of each criterion

tr.td:
a The longest lateral length of candidate well pads to be ranked
b The smallest skin factor of candidate well pads to be ranked

table-wrap.anchoringText: In this study, six candidate well pads will be evaluated and ranked using the F-AHP method as an example. It is assumed that all horizontal wells placed in their belonging well pad are of equal completion quality. The reservoir and well completion variables of these candidates are summarized in Table 14.
table-wrap.label: Table 14
table-wrap.caption: Parameters of candidates well pads for evaluation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Parameters of candidates well pads for evaluation

table-wrap.anchoringText: According to Shinha and Ramakrishnan (2011), a crossplot of the reservoir quality indicator and well completion indicator - namely the two individual grades calculated for reservoir and completion quality of each candidate - was introduced in this study to screen potential refracturing candidates. Using the relevant dataset from Table 15, a crossplot was obtained in Figure 14.
table-wrap.label: Table 15
table-wrap.caption: Grading and ranking of candidates

table-wrap.anchoringText: The sandstone members of the Cardium formation are occasionally capped by some highly permeable conglomerate layers that have varying thickness from a few inches to approximately 20 ft. A conglomerate member can act as a “thief” zone for the injected CO2 agent as a result of its high permeability (Dashtgard et al., 2008). To investigate the effects of a highly permeable conglomerate member on CO2 injection, permeability and porosity of the top layer were modified in the base model. Their values are listed in Table 16. In addition, a new set of relative permeability curves were generated for the conglomerate member, as plotted in Figure 18.
table-wrap.label: Table 16
table-wrap.caption: Geological parameters for conglomerate and sand

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological parameters for conglomerate and sand
